title: Different Kinds of Boxes (Data Types: Strings, Integers, Floats)
concept:
Imagine you're organizing your garage. You have different types of containers for different things:

  • üì¶ Cardboard boxes for storing books and papers (fragile text items)
  • üß∞ Plastic bins with numbers for counting screws and nails (whole numbers)
  • ‚öñÔ∏è Containers with measurement scales for liquids like paint (precise amounts with decimals)
  • ‚úÖ Yes/No labels for items that are either here or not (True/False)

You wouldn't store liquid paint in a cardboard box, right? And you wouldn't count screws with a measuring cup. You use the right container for the right type of thing.

Python works the same way! It has different "types" of data, and each type is suited for a specific purpose:

  • Strings (str) - Text and words. Like labels on boxes: "Hello", "Sarah", "123 Main St"
  • Integers (int) - Whole numbers for counting. Like counting screws: 5, 100, -42
  • Floats (float) - Numbers with decimal points for precise measurements. Like measuring paint: 3.14, 19.99, -0.5
  • Booleans (bool) - True or False values. Like yes/no questions: True, False

Why does this matter?

Because you can't do math with text, and you can't make "HELLO" uppercase if it's a number! Python needs to know what kind of data you're working with so it knows what operations make sense.

Think of it like this: if someone hands you a container, you need to know if it holds text, numbers, or true/false values before you know what you can do with it.

code_example.code:
# Let's explore Python's main data types!

# STRING - text wrapped in quotes
name = "Alice"
greeting = 'Hello, World!'
address = "123 Main Street"

print("STRINGS (text):")
print(f"name = {name}")
print(f"Type: {type(name)}")
print()

# INTEGER - whole numbers (no quotes, no decimal point)
age = 25
students = 100
temperature = -5

print("INTEGERS (whole numbers):")
print(f"age = {age}")
print(f"Type: {type(age)}")
print()

# FLOAT - numbers with decimal points
price = 19.99
pi = 3.14159
temperature_precise = 98.6

print("FLOATS (decimal numbers):")
print(f"price = {price}")
print(f"Type: {type(price)}")
print()

# BOOLEAN - True or False (capital T and F, no quotes)
is_student = True
has_license = False

print("BOOLEANS (True/False):")
print(f"is_student = {is_student}")
print(f"Type: {type(is_student)}")
print()

# What happens when you mix types?
print("MIXING TYPES:")
print(f"String + String: {'Hello' + ' ' + 'World'}")
print(f"Integer + Integer: {10 + 5}")
print(f"Float + Integer: {3.5 + 2}")
print(f"String * Integer: {'Ha' * 3}")
# print(f"String + Integer: {'Age: ' + 25}")  # This would cause an ERROR!

syntax_breakdown:
Let's break down each data type and understand the rules:

1. Strings (str) - The Text Type

  • What they are: Any text wrapped in quotes (single ' or double ")

    name = "Alice"     # Double quotes
greeting = 'Hi!'   # Single quotes (works the same)
message = "123"    # Even numbers in quotes are strings!

  • Key rule: MUST have matching quotes at start and end

    "Hello"  ‚úÖ Correct
'Hello'  ‚úÖ Also correct
"Hello'  ‚ùå Error - quotes don't match!

  • The type() function: Tells you what type a value is

    print(type("Alice"))  # Shows:

    Think of type() as asking "What kind of container is this?"

2. Integers (int) - The Whole Number Type

  • What they are: Whole numbers with NO decimal point and NO quotes

    age = 25        # Positive integer
count = 0       # Zero is an integer
debt = -500     # Negative integer

  • Key rule: NO quotes, NO decimal point

    age = 25       ‚úÖ Integer
age = "25"     ‚ùå String (has quotes)
age = 25.0     ‚ùå Float (has decimal point)

  • You can do math: +, -, *, /, //, %, **

    students = 20 + 5   # Addition: 25
groups = 20 // 5    # Division (whole number): 4
squared = 5 ** 2    # Exponent: 25

3. Floats (float) - The Decimal Number Type

  • What they are: Numbers with a decimal point

    price = 19.99
pi = 3.14159
temperature = -2.5
exact_value = 5.0  # Even whole numbers with .0 are floats!

  • Key rule: MUST have a decimal point (even if it's .0)

    price = 19.99  ‚úÖ Float
price = 20     ‚ùå Integer (no decimal point)

  • Mixing int and float: Result is always a float

    result = 5 + 2.5   # 5 (int) + 2.5 (float) = 7.5 (float)
print(type(result))  #

  • IEEE 754 Standard: Python uses 64-bit precision for floats (about 15-17 decimal digits of accuracy)

4. Booleans (bool) - The True/False Type

  • What they are: Only TWO possible values: True or False

    is_raining = True
has_license = False

  • Key rules:

    1. Must be capitalized: True and False (not true or false)
    2. NO quotes (with quotes they become strings)
    is_student = True    ‚úÖ Boolean
is_student = true    ‚ùå Error (not capitalized)
is_student = "True"  ‚ùå String (has quotes)

5. Mixing Types - What Works and What Doesn't

OperationExampleResult
String + String"Hello" + " World"‚úÖ "Hello World"
Integer + Integer5 + 3‚úÖ 8
Float + Integer5.5 + 2‚úÖ 7.5
String * Integer"Ha" * 3‚úÖ "HaHaHa"
String + Integer"Age: " + 25‚ùå TypeError!

The golden rule: You can't directly combine strings and numbers with +. You need to convert them first (we'll learn this next lesson!).

exercise.instructions:
Your Mission: Create a "Player Profile" program that demonstrates all four data types!

Requirements:

  1. Create variables for:
    • Player name (string)
    • Player level (integer)
    • Health points (float)
    • Is online (boolean)
  2. Use type() to verify each variable's type
  3. Display a formatted profile showing all the information
  4. Perform at least one math operation with numbers
  5. Try multiplying a string by an integer

Bonus Challenge: Calculate the player's health percentage (current health / max health * 100) and display it!

solution.explanation:
Breaking down the solution:

  1. Creating variables with different types:

    player_name = "DragonSlayer"  # String - has quotes
player_level = 42             # Integer - whole number, no quotes
health_points = 87.5          # Float - has decimal point
is_online = True              # Boolean - True/False, capitalized

    Each variable holds a different type of data, like different containers in your garage!

  2. Using type() to check data types:

    print(type(player_name))  # Output:

    The type() function is like asking Python: "What kind of container is this?" It returns the data type.

  3. Math with integers:

    next_level = player_level + 1  # 42 + 1 = 43

    You can do math with integers and floats. Python handles it automatically!

  4. String multiplication:

    battle_cry = "Victory" * 3  # "VictoryVictoryVictory"

    Multiplying a string by an integer repeats the string. This ONLY works with strings and integers - not string + integer!

  5. Float calculations:

    health_percent = (health_points / max_health) * 100
# (87.5 / 100.0) * 100 = 87.5

    Dividing floats gives you precise decimal results. Perfect for percentages!

  6. String methods (bonus):

    player_name.upper()  # "DRAGONSLAYER"

    Strings have built-in "methods" (special functions) like .upper(), .lower(), etc. We'll explore these more later!

Key Insight: Each data type has its own "superpowers":

  • Strings can be made uppercase/lowercase, sliced, concatenated
  • Integers and Floats can be used in math operations
  • Booleans are perfect for yes/no decisions (you'll use these LOTS in Module 3!)
solution.common_mistakes:
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Putting quotes around numbers when you want to do math:

    age = "25"       # ‚ùå This is a STRING
age = age + 1    # ‚ùå Error! Can't add number to string

age = 25         # ‚úÖ This is an INTEGER
age = age + 1    # ‚úÖ Works! Result: 26

    Rule: If you plan to do math, DON'T use quotes!

  2. Forgetting the decimal point for floats:

    price = 20       # This is an INTEGER (20)
price = 20.0     # This is a FLOAT (20.0)

# They look similar but are different types!
print(type(20))    # 
print(type(20.0))  #

  3. Wrong capitalization for booleans:

    is_ready = true    ‚ùå Error: 'true' is not defined
is_ready = TRUE    ‚ùå Error: 'TRUE' is not defined
is_ready = True    ‚úÖ Correct - capital T
is_ready = False   ‚úÖ Correct - capital F

    Python is case-sensitive! True and False are keywords, not variables.

  4. Trying to add strings and numbers directly:

    # ‚ùå This doesn't work:
print("Age: " + 25)  # TypeError: can only concatenate str to str

# ‚úÖ Solutions:
print("Age:", 25)           # Use comma (adds space automatically)
print(f"Age: {25}")         # Use f-string
print("Age: " + str(25))    # Convert to string first (next lesson!)

  5. Confusing / and //:

    result = 10 / 3    # Regular division: 3.3333... (float)
result = 10 // 3   # Floor division: 3 (integer, rounds down)

print(type(10 / 3))   # 
print(type(10 // 3))  #

  6. Thinking type() changes the type:

    age = "25"
print(type(age))  # ‚ùå This just CHECKS the type, doesn't change it!

age = int(age)    # ‚úÖ This CONVERTS it (we'll learn this in Lesson 3!)

    type() is like looking at a label - it doesn't change what's inside!

Pro Tip: When in doubt, use print(type(your_variable)) to check what type you're working with. It's like asking Python "What kind of box is this?" before you try to use it!

key_takeaways:
• Python has four main basic data types: str (strings), int (integers), float (decimals), and bool (True/False)
  • Strings are text in quotes: "Hello" or 'Hello'
  • Integers are whole numbers without quotes: 42, -5, 0
  • Floats are decimal numbers: 3.14, 19.99, -2.5
  • Booleans are True or False (capitalized, no quotes)
  • Use type(variable) to check what type of data a variable holds
  • You can do math with integers and floats, but NOT directly with strings
  • Mixing int and float in math gives you a float result
  • You CAN multiply a string by an integer to repeat it: "Hi" * 3 = "HiHiHi"
  • Each type has its own "rules" and "superpowers" - use the right type for the right job!
  • Python follows IEEE 754 standard for floats (64-bit, ~15-17 decimal digits precision)
